facts.text: On July 9 and 11, 1966, the petitioner's house and his business premises were searched by the 2nd respondent (1st Income-Tax Officer, A-III Ward, Bombay) as per the authorisation issued by the 1st respondent (the Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City-II, Bombay), under section 132(1) of the Income-tax Act, 1961.
During the searches, several documents were seized and a sum of Rs. 1,17,000/- was seized by the 2nd respondent.
A portion of the amount seized has been appropriated towards the arrears of income-tax due from the petitioner.

The searches and the seizures in question have taken place in the city of Bombay. Respondents 1 and 2 reside in that city. Their offices are situate in that city. Even the petitioner is residing in that city. The authorisation issued by the 1st respondent under section 132(1) was issued in that city.

The petitioner filed an application under section 132(11) of the Income-Tax Act, 1961, against the decision of the 1st respondent, which is pending before the Central Board of Direct Taxes, New Delhi (3rd respondent).
The 3rd respondent's office is in Delhi.
The order passed by the second respondent under section 132(5) is dated the 6th October 1966.

legal_issues.text: Whether this Court has jurisdiction to entertain this petition under Article 226 of the Constitution of India.
Whether the Central Government is a necessary party to the petition.
Whether challenging the vires of Section 132(5) of the Income-Tax Act, 1961, requires the Central Government as a necessary party.

petitioner_arguments.text: Central Government is a necessary party because the money seized (portion appropriated towards tax) has gone to the Consolidated Fund of India.
Central Government is a necessary party as the petitioner is challenging the vires of Section 132(5) of the Income-Tax Act, 1961.

Application under Section 132(11) pending before Central Board of Direct Taxes, New Delhi (3rd respondent); its decision would merge with the order of the 1st respondent, conferring jurisdiction on this Court.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 132(11) Income-Tax Act, 1961; Collector of Customs v. East India Commercial Co. Ltd.

petitioner_arguments.text: 3rd respondent has no jurisdiction to hear the application under Section 132(11); it is a necessary party with office in Delhi, conferring jurisdiction.
Under Section 132A(4)(a), Central Government liable for interest on assets retained under Section 132(5), making it a necessary party.
Authorisation issued by 1st respondent is void; searches and seizures illegal.

respondent_arguments.text: Preliminary objection: this Court has no jurisdiction to entertain this petition as the entire cause of action has arisen in the city of Bombay.

court_reasoning.text: Prima facie, the entire cause of action has arisen in the city of Bombay where searches took place, parties reside, offices are situated, and authorisation issued; reliefs fall outside jurisdiction of this Court under Article 226(1) or (2).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Entire cause of action in Bombay.

court_reasoning.text: Central Government not a necessary party; only validly realised revenue goes to Consolidated Fund; if seizures invalid, amount not part of Fund; for deciding validity, Central Govt not necessary.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Any and every sum seized does not become part of Consolidated Fund.

court_reasoning.text: Challenging vires of Central Act does not require Central Government as necessary party; no law prescribes it; CPC O.27A R.1,2 shows notice to AG sufficient, not joinder; distinguished Swadeshi Cotton Mills; agreed with Syed Hussain Ali.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Central Government not necessary party even for vires challenge.

court_reasoning.text: No merger as CBDT has not yet decided the application under s.132(11); Collector of Customs not applicable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellate authority has made no order.

court_reasoning.text: Petitioner cannot impose jurisdiction by claiming 3rd respondent necessary for relief declaring it has no jurisdiction; can withdraw application.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Device to impose jurisdiction not permitted.

court_reasoning.text: No claim under s.132A; reliefs dehors that provision.

holdings.text: This Court has no jurisdiction to entertain the petition.

precedents_cited.case_name: Swadeshi Cotton Mills Co. Ltd. v Sales Tax Officer
precedents_cited.relevance: Allahabad HC observation that State must be impleaded for vires challenge held unsupported by reason.

precedents_cited.case_name: Syed Hussain Ali v. The Durgah Committee, Ajmer
precedents_cited.relevance: Rajasthan HC: Union not necessary party for vires challenge if no relief claimed against it; notice to AG sufficient.

precedents_cited.case_name: Collector of Customs v. East India Commercial Co. Ltd. Calcutta
precedents_cited.relevance: Merger doctrine applies only when appellate authority makes order; not applicable here as no order yet.

statutes_cited.name: Income-Tax Act, 1961
statutes_cited.relevance: Searches/seizures under s.132(1); order under s.132(5); application under s.132(11); vires challenged; interest provision

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ jurisdiction; vires challenge under Arts 14,19(1)(f),31; ref in CPC O.27A

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Notice to AG for constitutional questions; optional addition of Central Govt

outcome.summary: The petition is dismissed with costs on the ground that this Court has no jurisdiction to entertain it, as the entire cause of action arose in Bombay. The court did not go into the merits.
outcome.costs: Dismissed with costs. Advocates fee Rs.

key_quotes.text: That being so, the reliefs prayed for in the petition, whether considered under sub-Article (1) of Article 226 or under Sub-Article (2) of Article 226, prima facie, fall outside the jurisdiction of this Court.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning on lack of territorial jurisdiction.

key_quotes.text: Any and every sum of money seized by an officer of the Central Government, does not become a part and parcel of the Consolidated Fund of India.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects argument that Central Govt necessary due to Consolidated Fund.

key_quotes.text: These provisions make it clear that the Central Government or the State Government as the case may be, is not a necessary party to a proceeding wherein the vires of any provision of law is challenged.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Holding on vires challenge not requiring Central Govt joinder.
